greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Initialize a(1)=R=1. Repeat: copy the last R preceding terms to current position; increment R; do twice: append the least integer that has not appeared in the sequence yet.
comment: Every positive integer n occurs floor((n+3)/2) times: 1 and 2 occur twice, 3 and 4 thrice, 5 and 6 four times, and so on.
example: a(5)=2, a(6)=3  -- copied two last terms
a(9)=3, a(10)=4, a(11)=5  -- copied three last terms
a(14)=4, a(15)=5, a(16)=6, a(17)=7  -- copied four last terms
a(18)=8, a(19)=9  -- appended two terms, and so on.
Comments from _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 28 2020, following a suggestion from _Paul Curtz_. (Start)
With an initial -1, 0, this may also be regarded as a triangle read by rows:
or as an array read by upward antidiagonals:
xref: If we prefix this with -1, 0, and then add 1 to every term, we get A051162.
results.author: _Alex Ratushnyak_, Mar 05 2013
